name: Neptune
name_theory: Neptune is named after the Roman god of the sea. The name reflects its deep blue coloration, reminiscent of the vast oceans on Earth, and also acknowledges its position as the most distant planet from the Sun at the time of its discovery.
description: Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun in the Solar System. It is a gas giant, similar in composition to Uranus, and has a deep blue coloration due to the presence of methane in its atmosphere.
distance_from_nearest_star: Approximately 4.5 billion kilometers from Neptune to the Sun

gallery.description: Neptune's atmosphere showing its blue coloration and cloud bands

interesting_facts: Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun in the Solar System, with an average distance of about 4.5 billion kilometers.
Neptune is a gas giant similar in composition to Uranus, with a deep blue coloration due to the presence of methane in its atmosphere.
Neptune has a complex atmosphere with dynamic weather patterns, including high-speed winds and massive storms, such as the Great Dark Spot observed by the Voyager 2 spacecraft.
Neptune has the strongest winds in the Solar System, with speeds reaching up to 2,100 kilometers per hour (1,300 miles per hour).
Neptune has a faint ring system similar to that of Uranus, composed of dark particles and debris.
Neptune has at least 14 known moons, including Triton, the largest moon, which orbits in a retrograde direction opposite to the planet's rotation.
Triton, Neptune's largest moon, is thought to be a captured Kuiper Belt object due to its retrograde orbit and geological activity, including cryovolcanism.
Neptune has been visited by only one spacecraft, Voyager 2, which flew by the planet in 1989 and provided valuable data and images of Neptune and its moons.
Neptune's magnetic field is tilted relative to its rotational axis and offset from the planet's center, possibly due to the presence of a metallic hydrogen layer in its interior.
Neptune's magnetic field is stronger than that of Uranus but weaker than those of Jupiter and Saturn.
Neptune has a deep and dynamic atmosphere with distinct cloud bands, including bright clouds of methane ice and dark storms.
Neptune's atmosphere undergoes seasonal changes due to its tilted axis and elliptical orbit, resulting in variations in cloud patterns and atmospheric dynamics.
Neptune has a faint system of rings composed of dust particles and debris, similar to those of Uranus but less extensive and prominent.
Neptune's rings were first discovered in 1984 by astronomers observing the planet's occultation of a star.
Neptune's rings are named after astronomers and scientists who made significant contributions to the study of the planet.
Neptune's moons vary in size and composition, with some having irregular shapes and others exhibiting geologically active surfaces.
Neptune's moons are believed to have formed from the debris of collisions between larger objects in the early Solar System, with Triton likely being a captured Kuiper Belt object.
Neptune's moons exhibit a wide range of features, including icy surfaces, craters, and geysers of nitrogen gas and dust.
Neptune's moons orbit the planet in relatively stable orbits, with some being in resonance with each other due to gravitational interactions.
